title: Henry Grover
text:
Henry Cushing Grover (April 1, 1927 – November 28, 2005), usually known as Hank Grover, was an American politician from the U.S. state of <a href="Texas">Texas</a> best known for his relatively narrow defeat in <a href="1972%20Texas%20gubernatorial%20election">1972</a>. He was a <a href="American%20conservatism">conservative</a> <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a>
Early life and education.
Grover was born in <a href="Corpus%20Christi%2C%20Texas">Corpus Christi</a>. Grover lived as a youth in <a href="San%20Antonio%2C%20Texas">San Antonio</a>. A <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a>, he graduated from the college-preparatory and all-male <a href="St.%20Thomas%20High%20School%20%28Houston%2C%20Texas%29">St. Thomas High School</a> in <a href="Houston%2C%20Texas">Houston</a>. He received his <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> degree in history and <a href="political%20science">political science</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20St.%20Thomas%20%28Houston%29">University of St. Thomas</a> and his <a href="Master%20of%20Arts">Master of Arts</a> degree in the same subjects from the <a href="University%20of%20Houston">University of Houston</a>. His master's <a href="thesis">thesis</a> was on <a href="Colonel%20House">Colonel Edward M. House</a> of Houston, a Democrat active in the campaign to elect <a href="Woodrow%20Wilson">Woodrow Wilson</a> as the <a href="U.S.%20President">U.S. President</a>.
1972 gubernatorial run.
Grover was elected to the <a href="Texas%20House%20of%20Representatives">Texas House of Representatives</a> in 1960, 1962, and 1964 as a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a>. In 1966, he switched parties and was elected to the <a href="Texas%20Senate%2C%20District%2015">District 15</a> of the <a href="Texas%20State%20Senate">Texas State Senate</a>. In the 1972 Republican gubernatorial primary, Grover led a field of five with 37,118 votes (32.6 percent). Houston businessman <a href="Albert%20Bel%20Fay">Albert Bel Fay</a> ran second with 24,329 ballots (21.3 percent). Three other largely unknown candidates shared a surprisingly large 41.8 percent of the vote. Grover carried the backing of prominent Houston developer and Republican activist <a href="James%20E.%20Lyon">James E. Lyon</a>, who discouraged a potential gubernatorial primary bid by <a href="Jim%20Reese%20%28Texas%20politician%29">Jim Reese</a>, then the mayor of <a href="Odessa%2C%20Texas">Odessa</a> in <a href="West%20Texas">West Texas</a>.
In an even lower turnout runoff primary, Grover defeated Fay (1913–1992), the Republican national committeeman from Texas (1960–1969). Grover received 37,842 votes (66.4 percent), some 700 more votes than he received in the first primary, to Fay's 19,166 (33.6 percent), or 5,000 fewer votes than he obtained in the primary. The <a href="Sharpstown">Sharpstown</a> bank scandal, which had damaged many of the state's Democratic leaders, worked to Grover's advantage, for he could depict himself as an untainted Republican nominee for governor. His uncompromising conservative, constitutionalist views may have hurt him among moderate voters in both parties.
Grover lost the <a href="general%20election">general election</a> by almost exactly 100,000 votes to the Democratic nominee, former state Representative <a href="Dolph%20Briscoe">Dolph Briscoe, Jr.</a>, of <a href="Uvalde%2C%20Texas">Uvalde</a>. Grover carried almost all of the state's urban centers. The final tally was 1,633,493 (47.9 percent) for Briscoe and 1,533,986 (45 percent) for Grover. Briscoe was a "minority governor" because he failed to garner a simple majority of the votes. The <a href="Hispanic">Hispanic</a> <a href="La%20Raza">La Raza</a> candidate, then 29-year-old <a href="Ramsey%20Muniz">Ramsey Muñiz</a>, received 214,118 votes (6 percent), nearly all believed to have been at Briscoe's expense. (Two other minor candidates shared 27,994 votes, or 0.8 percent.) Muñiz's support was insufficient to deny victory to Briscoe, but political analysts contend that Briscoe's margin was largely dependent on Hispanic voters in rural areas of south Texas who traditionally stuck with their Democratic nominees.
<a href="Ernest%20Angelo">Ernest Angelo</a>, the mayor of <a href="Midland%2C%20Texas">Midland</a> at the time and a leading state Republican, described his friend Grover as "his own worst enemy. He couldn't get along, let personal things interfere in the political realm." In retrospect, Angelo said that Grover's gubernatorial loss set back the development of the <a href="Republican%20Party%20of%20Texas">Republican Party of Texas</a> by a number of years. During the 1972 campaign, Grover had wanted Angelo to take the state chairmanship to replace George Williford of Austin, a Tower partisan.
Grover's Catholicism was apparently not an issue with Texas voters. Had he been elected, he would have become the first Catholic governor of the State of Texas. Many believed that Texas had supported Republican <a href="Herbert%20Hoover">Herbert Hoover</a> in 1928 because opponent <a href="Alfred%20E.%20Smith">Alfred E. Smith</a> was Roman Catholic. Texas, however, had voted narrowly in 1960 for <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a>, the nation's first Catholic president.
On the direction of GOP.
Grover and Republican Senator <a href="John%20G.%20Tower">John G. Tower</a> disagreed over the focus of the GOP. Grover wanted the party to move in a <a href="populism">populist</a> direction to attract those who had previously favored <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a> Governor <a href="George%20Wallace">George C. Wallace</a>, for president and combine those otherwise traditionally Democratic voters with the Republican base, consisting mostly of fiscal conservatives. Tower favored a different approach to expand the party by attracting middle-of-the-roaders who stressed "good government" and those with economically conservative views. Tower and Grover nearly came to fisticuffs in the 1972 campaign when <a href="Ernest%20Angelo">Ernest Angelo</a>, the new <a href="mayor">mayor</a> of <a href="Midland%2C%20Texas">Midland</a>, tried to get the two to work out their differences. The bitterness persisted. While Grover lost his race to Briscoe, Tower was a relatively easy winner for a third term in the Senate over Democrat <a href="Harold%20Sanders">Harold "Barefoot" Sanders</a>, a former federal judge. The Grover approach appeared to have been vindicated with the 1976 primary victory of former <a href="California">California</a> <a href="governor%20of%20California">Governor</a> <a href="Ronald%20W.%20Reagan">Ronald W. Reagan</a> in the first Texas GOP presidential primary in which voters chose the delegates. Indeed, Grover supported Reagan in 1976 over Tower's choice, then <a href="U.S.%20President">U.S. President</a> <a href="Gerald%20R.%20Ford">Gerald R. Ford, Jr.</a> Tower's approach was, however, consistent with the later successes in Texas of the two George Bushes. In his 1991 autobiography, Tower referred to Grover in only one paragraph.
1984 U.S. Senate campaign.
Tower announced in the summer of 1983 that he would not seek a fifth term. Grover, who had disagreed with Tower on many issues, therefore, entered the Republican primary held in May 1984. He fared poorly in that race. In the first primary, Republicans nominated Congressman <a href="William%20Philip%20Gramm">Phil Gramm</a> of <a href="College%20Station%2C%20Texas">College Station</a>, another convert to the GOP. Also seeking the 1984 Senate nomination were <a href="Robert%20Mosbacher%2C%20Jr.">Robert Mosbacher, Jr.</a>, of Houston, son of later U.S. <a href="Secretary%20of%20Commerce">Secretary of Commerce</a> <a href="Robert%20A.%20Mosbacher">Robert A. Mosbacher</a>, and conservative-to-<a href="Libertarianism">libertarian</a> Congressman <a href="Ron%20Paul">Ron Paul</a> of the district southwest of Houston. Gramm in turn defeated the Democratic nominee, then state Senator and later U.S. Representative <a href="Lloyd%20Doggett">Lloyd Doggett</a>, and went on to serve three terms in the U.S. Senate.
Challenging the "Johnson law".
Grover's reputation as a gadfly to the establishment surfaced again in 1995. As a private citizen, he sued the <a href="Texas%20Republican%20Party">Texas Republican Party</a> on the grounds that an elections rule, approved by the legislature in 1960, which permits a person to run for the White House and another office at the same time, is unconstitutional. He sued then party chairman, the conservative <a href="Thomas%20Pauken">Thomas Pauken</a> to prevent Gramm from filing for both offices in 1996.
"It violates the spirit of representative government in the Texas Constitution," Grover said in his lawsuit, filed at 126th State District Court in <a href="Travis%20County%2C%20Texas">Travis County</a>.
The rule, named for <a href="Lyndon%20B.%20Johnson">Lyndon B. Johnson</a>, allows a candidate to seek the presidency or the vice presidency and another office in the same election cycle. It was written in 1960 so that then U.S. Senator Johnson could run for re-election to the Senate as well as for president or vice president if he secured a national Democratic nomination. The Johnson rule was since used by former U.S. Senator <a href="Lloyd%20M.%20Bentsen%2C%20Jr.">Lloyd M. Bentsen, Jr.</a>, who ran for reelection in 1988 and was also the 1988 Democratic nominee for vice president. Several other states, including <a href="Connecticut">Connecticut</a> with Senator <a href="Joseph%20Lieberman">Joseph Lieberman</a> in 2000 and Delaware with Senator Joseph Biden in 2008, also permit presidential and vice presidential candidates to seek other offices at the same time, usually the U.S. Senate being the preferred choice.
Former Republican Senator <a href="Phil%20Gramm">Phil Gramm</a> may have benefited from the rule as well had he won his party's presidential nomination in 1996, but he withdrew from the presidential race even before the New Hampshire primary. Grover's suit went nowhere: the Johnson rule remains in effect in Texas.
1996 Republican Senate primary.
Grover's filing of the suit could have been motivated too by his own decision to challenge Gramm for renomination in the 1996 Republican senatorial primary. Though he won the support of some <a href="Second%20Amendment%20to%20the%20United%20States%20Constitution">Second Amendment</a> groups, Grover finished last in the three-man primary, with just 72,400 votes (7.34 percent). David Young, who termed himself "more moderate" than Gramm, finished second with 75,463 (7.65 percent). Gramm polled 838,339 (85 percent). Gramm, a former college economics professor, then defeated the Democrat Victor Morales, like Grover a former school teacher, in the general election.
Political philosophy.
The 1996 campaign offered a glimpse into Grover's later political views, largely compatible to those of then Republican presidential contender <a href="Patrick%20J.%20Buchanan">Patrick J. Buchanan</a>. Grover proposed a $10-a-barrel <a href="oil">oil</a> import tax to, in his view, reduce American dependence on imported oil, raise revenue to cut the deficit, and provide an incentive for independent oil drillers to find new wells. Grover proposed bringing home all American troops from Europe and placing them on the Mexican border from <a href="Brownsville%2C%20Texas">Brownsville, Texas</a> to <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego</a>, <a href="California">California</a>. He believes the military is needed to prevent <a href="illegal%20immigration%20to%20the%20United%20States">illegal immigration to the United States</a> and <a href="drug%20smuggling">drug smuggling</a>.
On <a href="abortion">abortion</a>, Grover said, "I'm 100 percent pro-life." He said that <a href="abortion">abortion</a> should be outlawed under all circumstances, even when the mother was raped: "As sad as those situations are, it's not that child's fault", he said. Speaking at <a href="Baylor%20University">Baylor University</a> in <a href="Waco">Waco</a>, Grover said that the most feminine thing a woman can do is give birth, adding that perhaps college-age women could not understand the full meaning of abortion. Grover also said that he agreed with the 1996 government shutdowns, saying it was "the only time Congress has faced up to the fact that the nation is bankrupt".
Obituary.
Until his death of <a href="Alzheimer%27s%20disease">Alzheimer's disease</a>, Grover resided in Houston with his wife, Kathleen D. Grover, the mother of his three sons and three daughters. The couple had married in 1952. Prior to entering politics, Grover was a history and civics teacher at Houston's <a href="Lamar%20High%20School%20%28Houston%2C%20Texas%29">Lamar Senior High School</a>. 
His eldest son, Bernard D. Grover, who graduated from St. Thomas High School, is known for his activism with the Convention Pro-Continuation of 1861, a moderate group devoted to Texas independence using the federal courts and Texas history and law for that purpose. Grover was a member of the Annunciation Catholic Church in Houston. He was <a href="cremation">cremated</a>.
"My husband was not a politician. He was a statesman. His wonderful integrity worked against him in the political process ... I just try to put all the politics out of my mind", Mrs. Grover said.
